message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the properties of water and the concept of conservation of mass. When an ice cube melts, it undergoes a physical change from a solid to a liquid. However, the mass of the substance remains the same. Therefore, the liquid form of the ice cube will weigh the same as the solid form, which is 2 ounces. Option (A) is incorrect because the liquid form of the ice cube will not "fly away." Option (B) and (C) are incorrect because the weight of the ice cube does not change when it melts.

This question requires basic knowledge about the properties of water and phase changes. When an ice cube melts, it undergoes a phase change from a solid to a liquid. However, the mass of the ice cube remains the same. Therefore, it will weigh the same, regardless of its form. Option (A) is incorrect because liquid water cannot fly away. Option (B) is incorrect because the weight of the ice cube does not increase when it melts. Option (C) is incorrect because the weight of the ice cube does not decrease when it melts.

The mass of the ice cube remains the same before and after melting, so it will weigh the same. Option (A) is incorrect because the liquid water will not "fly away." Option (B) and (C) are incorrect because the weight of the melted ice cube will remain 2 ounces.

Option (B) and (C) are incorrect because the weight of the melted ice cube does not change.
